Answer 4

column2: What is the primary purpose of Electron.js?
column3: To build cross-platform desktop applications using web technologies.
column4: To develop high-performance backend services.
column5: To create mobile-first web applications.
column6: To compile web code into native mobile apps.

column2: Which two main processes are fundamental to an Electron application's architecture?
column3: Main process and Renderer process.
column4: Server process and Client process.
column5: Background process and Foreground process.
column6: UI process and Logic process.

column2: In an Electron application which process has direct access to Node.js APIs and manages the application lifecycle?
column3: Main process.
column4: Renderer process.
column5: Preload script process.
column6: Web Worker process.

column2: What does 'Context Isolation' in Electron aim to prevent?
column3: Malicious code in a renderer process from accessing Node.js APIs directly.
column4: Renderer processes from communicating with each other.
column5: The main process from sending messages to the renderer.
column6: The application from accessing local files.

column2: Which package.json script typically specifies the entry point file for the main process of an Electron application?
column3: main
column4: start
column5: renderer
column6: electron

column2: Which module is responsible for creating and managing native browser windows in Electron?
column3: BrowserWindow.
column4: WebView.
column5: Window.
column6: AppWindow.

column2: What is a key benefit of using Electron for desktop application development?
column3: Leveraging existing web development skills and technologies.
column4: Superior performance compared to native applications.
column5: Smaller application bundle sizes.
column6: Automatic security updates for all dependencies.

column2: When an Electron app is started which event is typically emitted by the app module once Electron has finished initializing?
column3: 'ready'
column4: 'startup'
column5: 'launch'
column6: 'init'

column2: How does Electron load content into its renderer processes?
column3: By loading a local HTML file or a remote URL.
column4: By embedding a native UI framework.
column5: By compiling JavaScript into a native view.
column6: Only by loading remote URLs.

column2: What is the purpose of the app module in Electron?
column3: To control the application's event lifecycle.
column4: To manage rendering and UI.
column5: To handle database interactions.
column6: To provide access to web APIs.

column2: Which feature of Electron allows for multiple isolated UI processes each acting like a separate web page?
column3: Renderer processes.
column4: Main process.
column5: Preload scripts.
column6: Web Workers.

column2: What is a common drawback of Electron applications compared to purely native desktop applications?
column3: Higher memory usage and larger executable sizes.
column4: Inability to access local file systems.
column5: Lack of cross-platform compatibility.
column6: Difficulty in implementing modern UI designs.

column2: Which of the following is true about the Renderer process?
column3: It runs a full Chromium browser instance for rendering web content.
column4: It has direct access to Node.js and OS-level APIs without isolation.
column5: There can only be one Renderer process per application.
column6: It is primarily responsible for managing system resources.

column2: What is the default security model for new Electron applications?
column3: Context Isolation enabled and Node.js integration disabled in renderer processes.
column4: Node.js integration enabled by default in all processes.
column5: No sandboxing or isolation for renderer processes.
column6: All external URLs are automatically trusted.

column2: What is the role of a preload script in Electron?
column3: To run before a web page loads in a renderer process and expose Node.js APIs securely.
column4: To load all application assets before the main process starts.
column5: To handle all inter-process communication directly.
column6: To compile the entire application into a single executable.

column2: If all BrowserWindow instances are closed which event on the app module indicates that the application is ready to quit (except on macOS)?
column3: 'window-all-closed'
column4: 'all-windows-closed'
column5: 'quit'
column6: 'app-closed'

column2: What is the primary motivation behind Electron's sandboxing model for renderer processes?
column3: To enhance security by limiting the renderer's access to system resources.
column4: To improve application performance by offloading tasks to a sandbox.
column5: To allow the renderer to run untrusted code without any restrictions.
column6: To simplify the development of web components.

column2: Which module provides methods to control the entire lifecycle of an Electron application such as quitting or relaunching?
column3: app module.
column4: BrowserWindow module.
column5: dialog module.
column6: ipcMain module.

column2: When is it generally recommended to disable Node.js integration in the renderer process?
column3: When loading untrusted remote content or when not explicitly needed.
column4: Always regardless of content trust.
column5: Only when developing for macOS.
column6: Never as it breaks core Electron functionality.

column2: What does BrowserWindow.setAppDetails() allow you to customize?
column3: Application-specific details like the title bar and icon.
column4: Details of the app module.
column5: The content of the web page loaded.
column6: Security settings for the window.

column2: Why is Context Isolation considered a security best practice?
column3: It prevents the loaded web content from directly manipulating the window object or global Node.js APIs exposed by a preload script.
column4: It isolates all BrowserWindow instances from each other.
column5: It ensures that all renderer processes use the same Node.js version.
column6: It guarantees that all external network requests are encrypted.

column2: What distinguishes Electron's event-driven architecture?
column3: Both the main and renderer processes communicate primarily through events often via IPC.
column4: It uses a polling mechanism to check for state changes.
column5: Only the main process uses events the renderer is purely reactive.
column6: Events are exclusively used for UI interactions.

column2: Which module system is natively supported in Electron's main process?
column3: CommonJS and ES Modules.
column4: Only CommonJS.
column5: Only ES Modules.
column6: AMD.

column2: If an Electron application needs to gracefully terminate which app method should be used to initiate the shutdown sequence?
column3: app.quit()
column4: app.terminate()
column5: app.exit()
column6: app.destroy()

column2: Which of the following is NOT a default behavior of a new BrowserWindow instance?
column3: It has Node.js integration enabled by default.
column4: It creates a new renderer process.
column5: It can load local HTML files.
column6: It can be configured with various options (e.g. width height).

column2: How can you set a custom icon for your Electron application's BrowserWindow?
column3: By passing an icon option to the BrowserWindow constructor.
column4: By modifying the package.json file.
column5: By using a CSS property in the renderer.
column6: Electron automatically uses the favicon from the loaded HTML.

column2: What is the purpose of app.setAppLogsPath()?
column3: To specify a custom directory for application log files.
column4: To set the path for the application's executable.
column5: To define the default download location for files.
column6: To configure the path to the Electron framework itself.

column2: Which core architectural aspect makes Electron applications cross-platform?
column3: Embedding Chromium for UI and Node.js for backend logic which are cross-platform by nature.
column4: Using a custom Electron language that compiles to native code for each OS.
column5: Relying on specific OS-level APIs that are uniform across platforms.
column6: Utilizing web standards that are interpreted differently by each OS.

column2: What security consideration applies to loading external URLs in an Electron BrowserWindow without proper safeguards?
column3: It can expose the application to web vulnerabilities like XSS if nodeIntegration is enabled.
column4: It automatically isolates the content making it completely secure.
column5: External URLs are always blocked by default unless explicitly whitelisted.
column6: It is only a concern for local file access not remote content.

column2: How does Electron handle its main process being unresponsive?
column3: It usually does not affect the renderer processes directly; the main process might crash or become unresponsive independently.
column4: All renderer processes will immediately crash as well.
column5: The application automatically restarts the main process.
column6: The user is prompted to close the entire application.

column2: What command is typically used to start an Electron application during development?
column3: electron . or npm start (if configured in package.json).
column4: node index.js
column5: web-pack-dev-server
column6: npm build

column2: Which BrowserWindow option allows developers to create a frameless window (without a standard OS frame)?
column3: frame: false
column4: borderless: true
column5: noFrame: true
column6: chrome: false

column2: What is the relationship between Electron and Chromium?
column3: Electron embeds Chromium to display web content as its GUI.
column4: Electron is a separate project that competes with Chromium.
column5: Chromium is a tool used to debug Electron applications.
column6: Electron is a library for Chromium not an embedder.

column2: Which global object is available in both the main and renderer processes for inter-process communication?
column3: ipcRenderer (in renderer) and ipcMain (in main).
column4: dialog
column5: app
column6: BrowserWindow

column2: What is the primary function of process.type in Electron?
column3: To identify whether the current script is running in the 'main' or 'renderer' process.
column4: To determine the operating system Electron is running on.
column5: To check the current Node.js version.
column6: To identify the CPU architecture.

column2: Which package.json property can be used to pass additional command-line arguments to the Electron executable when running the app?
column3: electron-flags or custom scripts.
column4: cli-args
column5: app-options
column6: start-args

column2: How do you create a new browser window in the main process?
column3: By instantiating a new BrowserWindow object.
column4: By calling app.createWindow().
column5: By using ipcRenderer.createWindow().
column6: By writing HTML code for a new window.

column2: Which BrowserWindow option sets the initial width of the window?
column3: width
column4: initialWidth
column5: windowWidth
column6: client-width

column2: Which method of the app module is used to quit the application?
column3: app.quit()
column4: app.exit()
column5: app.close()
column6: app.terminate()

column2: How can you set a custom application menu for your Electron app?
column3: By using Menu.setApplicationMenu(Menu.buildFromTemplate(template)).
column4: By defining a _menu_ tag in the HTML.
column5: By setting the app.menu property.
column6: By calling BrowserWindow.setMenu().

column2: Which dialog module method is used to open a file selection dialog?
column3: dialog.showOpenDialog()
column4: dialog.openFile()
column5: dialog.selectFile()
column6: dialog.showFileDialog()

column2: What is the purpose of the Tray module?
column3: To add icons and context menus to the system's notification area.
column4: To manage system-level notifications.
column5: To create custom splash screens.
column6: To handle application updates.

column2: How can the main process send an asynchronous message to a renderer process?
column3: Using webContents.send().
column4: Using ipcMain.sendToRenderer().
column5: Using BrowserWindow.sendMessage().
column6: Using app.postMessage().

column2: Which module allows an Electron app to register global keyboard shortcuts that work even when the app is in the background?
column3: globalShortcut module.
column4: keyboard module.
column5: app.shortcuts module.
column6: accelerator module.

column2: How can you display a native OS notification from the main process?
column3: By using the Notification module.
column4: By calling alert() in the renderer process.
column5: By sending a message to webContents.showNotification().
column6: By using dialog.showMessageBox().

column2: Which method is used to open the developer tools for a specific BrowserWindow instance from the main process?
column3: win.webContents.openDevTools()
column4: win.openDevTools()
column5: app.openDevTools(win)
column6: webContents.openDevTools(win)

column2: What is the purpose of app.getPath('userData')?
column3: To get the path to the user's application data directory.
column4: To get the path to the application's executable.
column5: To get the path to the user's documents folder.
column6: To get the path where application logs are stored.

column2: How do you define a menu item that opens an external link in the user's default browser?
column3: By setting the role to 'openUrl' and url property (or using a custom click handler).
column4: By using shell.openExternal(url) in a click handler.
column5: By setting the type to 'link' and href property.
column6: Electron menus cannot open external links.

column2: When creating a new BrowserWindow which option makes it a child window of another BrowserWindow?
column3: parent
column4: childOf
column5: master
column6: owner

column2: Which dialog module method displays a modal message box with custom buttons?
column3: dialog.showMessageBox()
column4: dialog.alert()
column5: dialog.confirm()
column6: dialog.prompt()

column2: How do you attach a context menu to a Tray icon?
column3: By calling tray.setContextMenu(Menu.buildFromTemplate(template)).
column4: By adding a contextMenu option to the Tray constructor.
column5: By using app.setTrayContextMenu().
column6: Context menus are not supported for Tray icons.

column2: Which app module method can be used to restart the application with an optional path to the new executable?
column3: app.relaunch()
column4: app.restart()
column5: app.reboot()
column6: app.reload()

column2: What is webContents primarily used for from the main process?
column3: To control and interact with the content of a BrowserWindow (e.g. sending messages reloading).
column4: To manage application-wide settings.
column5: To create new BrowserWindow instances.
column6: To handle file system operations.

column2: Which power management feature can be monitored using the powerMonitor module?
column3: Changes in the system's power state (e.g. suspend resume).
column4: The application's CPU and memory usage.
column5: Network connectivity status.
column6: Battery charging cycles.

column2: How can you prevent a BrowserWindow from being resized by the user?
column3: By setting the resizable option to false in the constructor.
column4: By using CSS resize: none; in the renderer.
column5: By calling win.disableResizing().
column6: By setting minWidth and maxWidth to the same value.

column2: Which dialog method is used to show an error message box to the user?
column3: dialog.showErrorBox()
column4: dialog.showError()
column5: dialog.errorAlert()
column6: dialog.displayError()

column2: What does Menu.buildFromTemplate(template) return?
column3: A Menu object that can be set as an application or context menu.
column4: An HTML string representing the menu.
column5: A JavaScript object representing the menu structure.
column6: A list of menu item IDs.

column2: If a BrowserWindow is closed by the user what event is emitted on the window object before it is actually closed?
column3: 'close'
column4: 'closed'
column5: 'destroy'
column6: 'quit'

column2: Which method of the app module is used to get the path to the current executable?
column3: app.getPath('exe')
column4: app.getExecutablePath()
column5: app.getAppPath()
column6: app.getBinPath()

column2: To change the title of a BrowserWindow dynamically from the main process which method should be used?
column3: win.setTitle(newTitle)
column4: win.webContents.setTitle(newTitle)
column5: win.title = newTitle
column6: app.setWindowTitle(win newTitle)

column2: What is a typical use case for BrowserWindow.getParentWindow()?
column3: To establish a relationship between a modal dialog and its originating window.
column4: To find the main application window from any renderer process.
column5: To get the window that created the current BrowserWindow instance.
column6: To navigate the DOM tree of parent windows.

column2: Which property of BrowserWindow allows you to control whether the window should be shown in the macOS Dock?
column3: skipTaskbar (or skipPager on Linux setSkipTaskbar(true)).
column4: hideFromDock
column5: showInDock
column6: dockBehavior

column2: How do you create a system tray icon that responds to user clicks?
column3: Instantiate new Tray(iconPath) and attach event listeners like 'click'.
column4: Use app.setTrayIcon(iconPath).
column5: Implement a custom HTML element for the tray.
column6: Electron does not support interactive tray icons.

column2: Which app module event is emitted when the application is about to quit?
column3: 'will-quit'
column4: 'before-quit'
column5: 'quitting'
column6: 'shutdown'

column2: If you want to prevent a BrowserWindow from closing when the user clicks the close button what event can you listen for and prevent default?
column3: The 'close' event on the BrowserWindow instance.
column4: The 'beforeunload' event in the renderer.
column5: The 'window-all-closed' event on app.
column6: The 'destroy' event on the BrowserWindow.

column2: Which property of a BrowserWindow allows you to make it full screen?
column3: fullscreen: true (or setFullScreen(true)).
column4: maximized: true
column5: stretch: true
column6: display: 'full'

column2: What does powerMonitor.on('suspend' ...) allow you to do?
column3: Execute code before the system enters a suspended state.
column4: Monitor the battery level.
column5: Prevent the system from suspending.
column6: Detect when an application crashes.

column2: How can you dynamically add or remove menu items from an existing application menu?
column3: By modifying the Menu object obtained from Menu.getApplicationMenu() and calling setApplicationMenu() again.
column4: Menus are static and cannot be changed after creation.
column5: By directly manipulating the DOM of the menu in the renderer.
column6: Electron automatically updates menus based on application state.

column2: What is the significance of the BrowserWindow webPreferences option?
column3: It controls various settings for the renderer process such as nodeIntegration and contextIsolation.
column4: It defines the styling and appearance of the window frame.
column5: It specifies the network proxy settings for the application.
column6: It determines the operating system compatibility of the window.

column2: Which app module method ensures only a single instance of your application is running?
column3: app.requestSingleInstanceLock()
column4: app.ensureSingleton()
column5: app.lockInstance()
column6: app.allowSingleInstance()

column2: What are BrowserWindow minWidth and minHeight options used for?
column3: To set the minimum dimensions below which the window cannot be resized.
column4: To set the initial dimensions of the window.
column5: To define the size of the window when it's minimized.
column6: To prevent the window from being moved too close to screen edges.

column2: How do you programmatically close a specific BrowserWindow instance from the main process?
column3: By calling win.close().
column4: By calling win.destroy().
column5: By calling app.closeWindow(win).
column6: By sending an IPC message to the renderer to close itself.

column2: How does a renderer process typically access Node.js APIs in a secure Electron application (with context isolation enabled)?
column3: Through an API exposed by a preload script using contextBridge.
column4: Directly by calling require() anywhere in the renderer.
column5: By sending a synchronous IPC message to the main process.
column6: It cannot access Node.js APIs at all.

column2: What is the primary language used for developing the UI and frontend logic in an Electron renderer process?
column3: JavaScript HTML and CSS.
column4: Python.
column5: Java.

column2: What is the main purpose of a preload script?
column3: To inject custom scripts into the renderer's global scope before web content loads.
column4: To load all external libraries before the application starts.
column5: To handle all the main process logic.
column6: To define the application's build process.

column2: How does a renderer process send an asynchronous message to the main process?
column3: Using ipcRenderer.send().
column4: Using ipcMain.sendToMain().
column5: Using app.sendMessageToMain().
column6: Using window.postMessageToMain().

column2: Which ipcRenderer method is used to send a message to the main process and await a response?
column3: ipcRenderer.invoke()
column4: ipcRenderer.sendSync()
column5: ipcRenderer.request()
column6: ipcRenderer.call()

column2: What is a common way to persist client-side data in an Electron renderer process?
column3: localStorage sessionStorage or IndexedDB.
column4: Directly writing to the file system using Node.js fs module (without contextBridge).
column5: Using a server-side database.
column6: By sending data to the main process for every change.

column2: Which web API allows an Electron app to access the user's camera or microphone?
column3: navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia()
column4: electron.camera.access()
column5: app.getMediaDevices()
column6: BrowserWindow.getMedia()

column2: If contextIsolation is enabled how can a renderer access global variables or functions defined by Node.js in the main process?
column3: Through APIs exposed by the preload script via contextBridge.
column4: Directly as contextIsolation only applies to require().
column5: It can't; contextIsolation completely blocks all access.
column6: By calling a synchronous IPC method on ipcRenderer.

column2: How can a renderer process listen for messages sent from the main process?
column3: Using ipcRenderer.on().
column4: Using ipcMain.receive()
column5: Using app.onRendererMessage()
column6: Using window.addEventListener('message') without IPC.

column2: What is a key difference in how Node.js APIs are typically accessed in an Electron renderer compared to a standard web browser?
column3: Electron provides access to Node.js APIs while standard browsers do not.
column4: Node.js APIs are more limited in Electron's renderer than in a browser.
column5: Node.js APIs are always globally available without any setup in Electron.
column6: Electron requires special browser plugins for Node.js access.

column2: Why might you choose a frontend framework like React Vue or Angular for your Electron renderer process?
column3: To efficiently manage complex UI states and component-based development.
column4: To gain direct access to Node.js APIs.
column5: To reduce the overall application bundle size.
column6: To enable server-side rendering for desktop apps.

column2: What is the main security implication if nodeIntegration is enabled in a renderer process that loads untrusted external content?
column3: Malicious scripts in the web content could potentially access system resources.
column4: It would only affect the performance of the renderer.
column5: The application would automatically be blocked by the operating system.
column6: It would prevent the renderer from displaying images.

column2: How do you enable drag-and-drop functionality for files from the OS into an Electron application's renderer?
column3: By handling dragover and drop events on DOM elements and using event.dataTransfer.files.
column4: Electron automatically handles all drag-and-drop operations.
column5: By calling BrowserWindow.enableDragAndDrop().
column6: By using the electron.dragAndDrop module.

column2: What does window.open() do in an Electron renderer process by default?
column3: It opens a new BrowserWindow instance.
column4: It opens a new tab in the current browser window.
column5: It navigates the current BrowserWindow to a new URL.
column6: It only opens external URLs in the default system browser.

column2: Which HTML element was historically used in Electron to embed other web content within a BrowserWindow (now largely deprecated)?
column3: _webview_
column4: _iframe_ (only for regular web content)
column5: _embed_
column6: _frame_

column2: When receiving an IPC message from the main process what object typically contains the message arguments in the renderer?
column3: The second argument of the ipcRenderer.on callback.
column4: The event object's detail property.
column5: A global variable named ipcMessageArgs.
column6: It's directly accessible as message.args.

column2: What is contextBridge.exposeInMainWorld() used for?
column3: To safely expose Node.js APIs or custom functions from the preload script to the renderer's global scope.
column4: To make main process functions available directly to the web content.
column5: To bridge CSS styles between multiple renderer processes.
column6: To connect two separate web workers.

column2: What is a primary consideration when structuring a preload script for security?
column3: Exposing only the minimal necessary APIs to the renderer and carefully validating inputs.
column4: Exposing all Node.js APIs to maximize functionality.
column5: Making sure the preload script is as small as possible.
column6: Ensuring the preload script runs before any HTML loads.

column2: If a renderer needs to perform a synchronous operation that requires main process access which ipcRenderer method is generally discouraged and why?
column3: ipcRenderer.sendSync() because it blocks the renderer process.
column4: ipcRenderer.invoke() because it's too complex.
column5: ipcRenderer.send() because it's asynchronous.
column6: contextBridge.exposeInMainWorld() because it creates security risks.

column2: What is the role of document.getElementById('my-element') in a renderer process?
column3: To access an HTML element by its ID for manipulation.
column4: To fetch data from a server.
column5: To create a new window.
column6: To send a message to the main process.

column2: What might happen if nodeIntegration is enabled in a renderer process loading an external untrusted website and that website executes arbitrary JavaScript?
column3: The arbitrary JavaScript could potentially access local file system execute processes or perform other privileged Node.js operations.
column4: The website would only be able to access its own localStorage.
column5: The Electron application would immediately crash.
column6: The website's JavaScript would be blocked by default.

column2: How do you share data between different renderer processes (different BrowserWindow instances)?
column3: Through the main process using IPC or by using shared storage mechanisms like localStorage (if paths align).
column4: Directly between renderer processes using window.postMessage().
column5: By using a global shared object in the renderer.
column6: It's not possible to share data between renderer processes.

column2: Which preload script option is used to specify the path to the preload script file?
column3: webPreferences.preload in the BrowserWindow constructor.
column4: webPreferences.script
column5: preloadScript
column6: main.preload

column2: When developing a UI with a framework like React in Electron where does the React application typically render?
column3: Within the HTML document loaded by the renderer process.
column4: Directly on the main process.
column5: In a separate Node.js process.
column6: As a native UI component outside the Chromium window.

column2: What is the purpose of webPreferences.sandbox: true?
column3: To enable Chromium's sandboxing for the renderer process for enhanced security.
column4: To isolate CSS styles between different components.
column5: To create a separate Node.js environment for each renderer.
column6: To run the renderer process in a virtual machine.

column2: What is the impact of disabling webSecurity in webPreferences?
column3: It allows arbitrary CORS requests and local file access from the renderer significantly reducing security.
column4: It improves the performance of web content loading.
column5: It disables all network requests from the renderer.
column6: It enables Node.js integration by default.

column2: How can you inject a global JavaScript variable or function into the renderer process from the main process *without* using a preload script (and without context isolation)?
column3: By executing win.webContents.executeJavaScript() or win.webContents.send() and then setting a global from the renderer. (Less secure and generally discouraged).
column4: It's not possible without a preload script.
column5: By directly modifying the window object from the main process.
column6: Electron automatically syncs main process globals to the renderer.

column2: When integrating a UI framework like Vue.js where would you typically initialize the Vue app?
column3: In the renderer process's main JavaScript file after the DOM is ready.
column4: In the main process before any BrowserWindow is created.
column5: Within the preload script.
column6: Vue.js cannot be used in Electron.

column2: If you need to access system information (e.g. OS version) from the renderer how should it be done securely?
column3: Expose a method via contextBridge in the preload script that calls Node.js os module functions.
column4: Directly use require('os') in the renderer if nodeIntegration is enabled.
column5: Send an IPC message to the main process and await the response.
column6: It's not possible to get system info from the renderer.

column2: What are some challenges when upgrading Electron while using a frontend framework that has specific Chromium version dependencies?
column3: Compatibility issues with the new Chromium version that might break parts of the framework or its libraries.
column4: Electron upgrades automatically handle all framework dependencies.
column5: Frontend frameworks are completely independent of Chromium versions.
column6: Only Node.js compatibility is a concern not Chromium.

column2: Which event listener would you typically use in the renderer to detect when the entire HTML document has been loaded and parsed?
column3: DOMContentLoaded
column4: load (for all resources including images)
column5: ready
column6: documentReady

column2: How can a preload script expose a Node.js fs module method (e.g. fs.readFile) securely to the renderer?
column3: By wrapping fs.readFile in a function in the preload script and exposing that function via contextBridge.
column4: Directly expose the fs module via contextBridge.
column5: Simply make global.fs = require('fs') in the preload.
column6: It's not possible to expose fs securely.

column2: What is a common use case for a preload script to interact with the DOM?
column3: To inject polyfills or modify global objects before the main web content loads.
column4: To create a new BrowserWindow instance.
column5: To handle all application-level IPC communication.
column6: To package the application for distribution.

column2: Why is it important to carefully manage dependencies (like npm packages) in the renderer process?
column3: Unnecessary or large dependencies can increase the application's bundle size and load time.
column4: Renderer dependencies directly affect the main process's memory usage.
column5: npm packages cannot be used in the renderer process.
column6: They can cause conflicts with native OS libraries.

column2: What is the primary reason for Inter-Process Communication (IPC) in Electron?
column3: To enable communication between the main process and renderer processes.
column4: To allow web pages to communicate with each other directly.
column5: To facilitate communication between Electron and external web servers.
column6: To manage multi-threading within a single process.

column2: Which module is used in the main process to listen for messages from renderer processes?

column4: ipcRenderer
column5: app.ipc

column2: Which module is used in the renderer process to send messages to the main process?

column4: ipcMain
column5: app.ipc
column6: rendererIpc

column4: By calling ipcMain.sendToRenderer() directly.
column5: By emitting an event on the app module.
column6: By using BrowserWindow.postMessage().

column2: What ipcRenderer method is used for a one-way message from the renderer to the main process without expecting a response?

column4: ipcRenderer.request()
column5: ipcRenderer.invoke()
column6: ipcRenderer.call()

column2: What ipcMain method is used to listen for asynchronous messages sent from a renderer process via ipcRenderer.send()?

column4: ipcMain.handle()
column5: ipcMain.receive()
column6: ipcMain.listen()

column2: What is the key difference between ipcRenderer.send() and ipcRenderer.invoke()?

column4: send() is synchronous invoke() is asynchronous.
column5: send() is for main-to-renderer invoke() is for renderer-to-main.
column6: send() can only send strings invoke() can send objects.

column2: Which ipcMain method is used to handle messages sent from a renderer process via ipcRenderer.invoke() and send a response back?
column3: ipcMain.handle()
column4: ipcMain.on()
column5: ipcMain.call()
column6: ipcMain.respond()

column2: What is contextBridge specifically designed for in the context of IPC?

column4: To bridge the gap between HTML and CSS.
column5: To allow direct synchronous access to Node.js APIs from the renderer.
column6: To facilitate communication between two different renderer processes.

column2: When using ipcRenderer.invoke() and ipcMain.handle() what is the nature of the communication?
column3: Asynchronous request-response.
column4: Synchronous one-way.
column5: Synchronous request-response.
column6: Asynchronous one-way.

column2: What data types can be sent over Electron's IPC channels?
column3: Primitive values arrays objects and certain native objects that can be serialized by the Structured Clone Algorithm.
column4: Only strings and numbers.
column5: Only JSON-serializable objects.
column6: Any JavaScript object including functions and DOM elements.

column2: What is a potential pitfall of using ipcRenderer.sendSync()?
column3: It blocks the renderer process until the main process responds leading to a frozen UI.
column4: It can only send primitive data types.
column5: It is less secure than ipcRenderer.send().
column6: It requires complex error handling mechanisms.

column2: How can you handle errors that occur during ipcRenderer.invoke() calls?

column4: Errors are automatically logged to the main process console.

column2: What is a best practice for structuring IPC listeners in the main process?

column4: Create a separate ipcMain.on listener for each renderer process.
column5: Only use synchronous IPC to simplify error handling.
column6: Place all IPC logic directly inside the BrowserWindow constructor.

column4: Using event.sender.send(channel ...args).

column6: It's not possible to reply to ipcRenderer.send() messages.

column2: Why is it crucial to sanitize and validate any data received via IPC from a renderer process in the main process?

column2: What is the purpose of the channel argument in IPC methods like ipcRenderer.send(channel ...args)?

column4: To specify the target renderer process ID.

column2: Can IPC be used to send custom JavaScript objects (e.g. instances of classes) between processes directly?

column4: No only primitive data types can be sent.
column5: Yes but only if they are JSON serializable.

column2: What is a common pattern for main-to-renderer communication when the main process needs to update UI based on a system event?

column4: Main process directly manipulates the DOM of the renderer.

column2: Which best practice helps prevent memory leaks related to IPC listeners?

column4: Always use ipcRenderer.invoke instead of ipcRenderer.send.
column5: Limit the number of messages sent over IPC.
column6: Keep all IPC listeners in a single large function.

column2: What happens if ipcRenderer.invoke() is called but there is no ipcMain.handle() listener for that channel in the main process?

column5: The message will be silently dropped.
column6: The main process will automatically create a default handler.

column2: How would you ensure that an API exposed via contextBridge is read-only from the renderer?

column2: What is a disadvantage of using synchronous IPC (ipcRenderer.sendSync())?

column4: It is less secure than asynchronous IPC.
column5: It uses more system resources.
column6: It is difficult to debug.

column4: A plain object directly.
column5: A callback function that the renderer can execute.

column4: 1MB per message.

column2: What could be a reason to prefer asynchronous IPC over synchronous IPC?

column5: Asynchronous IPC has better error handling.
column6: Synchronous IPC is inherently insecure.

column4: It prevents network attacks on the renderer process.
column5: It reduces the application's memory footprint.
column6: It ensures that all IPC messages are encrypted.

column2: Why is contextIsolation enabled by default in modern Electron versions?

column4: To isolate CSS styles between different UI components.

column2: What is a general principle for minimizing an Electron application's attack surface?
column3: Disable or restrict all unnecessary features modules and permissions.
column4: Enable all features to provide maximum functionality.

column2: Why is it important to regularly update Electron and its dependencies?
column3: To incorporate security patches bug fixes and performance improvements.
column4: To gain access to new UI features only.
column5: Updates typically increase application size.

column4: Disabling contextIsolation.
column5: Enabling nodeIntegration.

column2: If your Electron app needs to execute an external executable how should this be done securely from the main process?

column4: Directly using child_process.exec() with user-provided commands.

column5: To isolate the application from the operating system entirely.

column2: Which security measure prevents a BrowserWindow from loading arbitrary external content?

column2: What is a common vulnerability if nodeIntegration is enabled in an Electron renderer process?

column4: Slowdowns in UI rendering performance.
column5: Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) issues.

column2: How should you store sensitive user data (e.g. API tokens passwords) in an Electron application?

column4: Directly in localStorage.
column5: In plain text files on the user's file system.
column6: Hardcoded within the application's source code.

column2: Why is input validation critical for data passed over IPC?

column4: It improves the performance of IPC communication.
column5: It prevents network latency.
column6: It ensures data types are automatically converted.

column2: What is the risk of using webPreferences.allowRunningInsecureContent: true?

column2: How can you protect your Electron app against common web vulnerabilities like SQL injection if it interacts with a local Node.js backend?

column4: By disabling JavaScript in the renderer.

column6: By restricting the app to only local URLs.

column2: What is the primary benefit of contextBridge.exposeInMainWorld() over simply adding properties to window in a preload script (without context isolation)?
column3: It creates a secure isolated bridge between the preload script's context and the renderer's window object.
column4: It allows direct access to Node.js modules from the renderer.
column5: It improves the performance of exposed APIs.
column6: It makes the exposed APIs available only to trusted domains.

column2: If your Electron application serves a local HTTP server what security considerations apply?

column6: It's purely a UI preference with no security implications.

column2: When handling user-provided file paths in the main process what is a crucial security step?
column3: Sanitize and validate paths and ideally restrict operations to a known safe directory.
column4: Trust all user-provided paths implicitly.
column5: Automatically resolve all paths to absolute paths.
column6: Encrypt all path strings before use.

column2: What is the purpose of app.setAsDefaultProtocolClient() regarding security?
column3: It registers your app to handle a custom protocol which requires careful validation of received URLs to prevent command injection.
column4: It sets the default web browser for the user.
column5: It establishes a secure communication protocol for IPC.
column6: It ensures all external links are opened by your app.

column2: What is the risk of using webPreferences.enableRemoteModule: true?
column3: It allows arbitrary access to main process modules (like app dialog Menu) from the renderer greatly increasing the attack surface.
column4: It causes the application to crash on startup.
column5: It makes the app unresponsive.
column6: It's only a performance concern.

column2: To prevent JavaScript injection attacks when displaying dynamic content from a database in the renderer what should be done?
column3: Sanitize all HTML content before injecting it into the DOM (e.g. using a DOMPurify-like library).
column4: Display content directly without any sanitization.
column5: Only use textContent instead of innerHTML.
column6: Disable all CSS styles.

column2: Why should you avoid enabling nodeIntegration in *all* renderer processes by default?
column3: It gives every renderer process direct access to powerful Node.js APIs which can be exploited by malicious web content.
column4: It complicates the development workflow.
column5: It is only useful for debugging purposes.
column6: It makes the application incompatible with certain web technologies.

column2: What is a common security best practice for handling sensitive environment variables in Electron?
column3: Load them in the main process and pass only necessary sanitized data to renderers via IPC.
column4: Expose all environment variables to all renderer processes.
column5: Store them directly in package.json.
column6: Hardcode them in the source code.

column2: If an Electron app uses localStorage for storing data what is a security consideration?
column3: localStorage is not encrypted and can be accessed by other websites if webSecurity is disabled or compromised.
column4: localStorage data is automatically synchronized to the cloud.
column5: localStorage is only accessible from the main process.
column6: localStorage is perfectly secure for sensitive data.

column2: What is the purpose of app.disableHardwareAcceleration() from a security perspective?
column3: It can mitigate potential vulnerabilities related to GPU-accelerated content especially when displaying untrusted content.
column4: It makes the application run faster on older hardware.
column5: It prevents the application from accessing network resources.
column6: It ensures that all content is rendered in software mode.

column2: When building Electron apps what is the importance of auditing npm dependencies?
column3: To identify and mitigate known vulnerabilities in third-party libraries.
column4: To reduce the number of dependencies.
column5: To ensure all dependencies are open source.
column6: To automatically update all dependencies.

column2: What is the primary danger of deserializing untrusted JSON or JavaScript objects in an Electron app?
column3: It can lead to arbitrary code execution if the deserializer is vulnerable (e.g. prototype pollution).
column4: It only causes data corruption.
column5: It slows down the application's startup time.
column6: It makes the application incompatible with certain OS versions.

column2: How can you ensure that a BrowserWindow always opens external URLs in the user's default browser not within a new Electron window?
column3: By handling the new-window event on webContents and using shell.openExternal().
column4: By setting nativeWindowOpen: false in webPreferences.
column5: By disabling window.open() in the renderer.
column6: Electron automatically opens all external URLs in the default browser.

column2: Which tool is built into Electron for debugging renderer processes?
column3: Chromium DevTools.
column4: Node.js Debugger.
column5: VS Code debugger.
column6: Electron Inspector.

column4: win.openDevTools()
column5: app.openDevTools()
column6: console.openDevTools()

column2: To debug the main process of an Electron application using VS Code what file typically needs to be configured?

column4: settings.json
column5: tasks.json
column6: debug.config

column2: What is 'hot-reloading' in the context of Electron development?
column3: Updating code changes in the running application without a full reload preserving application state.
column4: Automatically restarting the application after every change.
column5: Compiling the entire application into an executable.
column6: Debugging code in production.

column2: Which tool or module can be used to automatically restart the main process and reload renderer processes on code changes?
column3: electron-reloader or similar development tools.
column4: npm watch
column5: webpack-dev-server (by itself)
column6: gulp reload

column2: How can you effectively log messages from both the main and renderer processes for debugging?
column3: Use a logging library that writes to files from both processes or pipe renderer console.log to main.
column4: Only use console.log in the main process.
column5: Renderer logs are always visible in the main process console.
column6: Only log errors not regular messages.

column2: What is the purpose of source maps in Electron development?

column4: To create a visual representation of the application's architecture.
column5: To optimize application startup time.
column6: To encrypt the application's source code.

column2: Which testing framework is specifically designed for testing Electron applications with a focus on end-to-end testing?

column2: How do you pause execution and inspect variables in the main process using VS Code?
column3: By setting breakpoints in the main process's JavaScript files.

column5: Main process cannot be debugged.

column2: What command is commonly used to install project dependencies during development?

column4: npm build
column5: npm start
column6: npm test

column2: When debugging a preload script where would you typically set breakpoints?

column4: In the main process's launch.json.
column5: Preload scripts cannot be debugged.
column6: Directly in the BrowserWindow constructor.

column2: What is a common technique for performance profiling an Electron renderer process?

column6: Using Node.js built-in profiler.

column4: 'chrome'
column5: 'javascript'
column6: 'web'

column2: What is the purpose of electron-debug?
column3: To enhance the development experience with features like automatic DevTools opening reload shortcuts and crash reporting.
column4: To debug the Electron framework itself.
column5: To automatically fix bugs in the application.
column6: To optimize application startup time.

column2: How can you ensure consistent Node.js versions across development environments for an Electron project?
column3: Using Node Version Manager (NVM) or specifying engines.node in package.json with a tool like nvmrc.
column4: Electron automatically manages Node.js versions.

column6: It's not critical for development workflow.

column2: Which type of testing would Spectron primarily be used for?

column4: Unit testing individual functions.

column6: Performance testing of rendering speed.

column2: What is a common problem when debugging IPC issues?
column3: Mismatched channel names incorrect arguments or listeners not being attached/removed correctly.
column4: IPC calls are always perfectly reliable.
column5: Debugging IPC is the easiest part of Electron development.
column6: IPC only fails due to network issues.

column4: It's not possible to attach to a running process.

column2: What is the role of webpack in an Electron development workflow?

column4: To create native installers for the application.
column5: To manage Node.js versions.
column6: To serve as the Electron main process entry point.

column2: When logging from the renderer process where do console.log messages appear by default?

column6: They are suppressed by default.

column2: What is a common challenge when setting up hot-reloading for an Electron main process?
column3: Changes to the main process often require a full restart of the Electron application making true hot-reloading difficult.
column4: Hot-reloading is always straightforward for the main process.
column5: Only CSS changes can be hot-reloaded in the main process.
column6: Hot-reloading is a renderer-only concept.

column4: 'unfocus'
column5: 'inactive'

column2: How can you enable verbose logging for Electron's internal processes?

column4: By setting app.enableVerboseLogging() in the main process.
column5: Electron does not support verbose internal logging.
column6: By increasing the Node.js verbosity level.

column2: What is the benefit of integrating automated testing (e.g. with Jest for unit tests) into your Electron development workflow?
column3: To ensure code quality catch regressions early and speed up the development cycle.

column3: Using module bundlers like Webpack or Rollup for code splitting and lazy loading.

column2: If your Electron app is slow to start what debugging technique might you employ?
